Permission to not have it polished in the first draft exists.  

By removing the primary obstacle, you ease every other aspect.  

The “slowest hiker” could be another person.  

This could be a boss who won’t approve a project.  

It could also be the finance department blocking the budget.  

A client who won’t sign on the dotted line is another example.  

To reduce friction with another person, use a friendly approach.  

Send him an email.  

Instead of asking if he has done the work, go see him.  

Ask him, “What obstacles are holding you back?”  

Then ask, “How can I help remove these?”  

Instead of pestering him, offer sincere support.  

You will get a warmer reply this way.  

When our children were little, I was in graduate school.  

My wife felt strained by the demands of caring for them.  

She didn’t know what to do about it.  

I was reading about the Theory of Constraints at the time.  

As we applied the steps, we identified a primary obstacle.  

Lack of time to plan, think, and prepare was the issue.  

With three little children, uninterrupted time was nearly impossible.  

We worked to remove this obstacle.  

I opted out of many extracurricular activities.  

I stayed home in the evenings.  

We found someone to care for the children during the week.  

As a result, we were more engaged with our children.  

We both ended up doing less, but doing it better.  

Removing obstacles doesn’t have to be hard.  

It doesn’t require superhuman effort.  

We can start small.  

It’s like dislodging a boulder at the top of a hill.  

All it takes is a small shove.  

Then momentum will naturally build.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Identifying and removing obstacles can significantly enhance productivity and engagement in both personal and professional contexts.
